factoid: Prince Andrew was pale and gloomy like everyone in the regiment.
Prince Andrew paced up and down from the border of one patch to another at the edge of the meadow beside an oatfield.
Prince Andrew had his head bowed and his arms behind his back.
Prince Andrew had nothing to do and no orders to be given.
The killed were dragged from the front.
The wounded were carried away.
The ranks closed up.
If any soldiers ran to the rear they returned immediately and hastily.
Prince Andrew considered it his duty to rouse the courage of the men and to set them an example.
Prince Andrew walked about among the ranks.
Prince Andrew soon became convinced that rousing the courage was unnecessary.
Prince Andrew soon became convinced that there was nothing he could teach the men.
All the powers of Prince Andrew's soul and every soldier's soul were unconsciously bent on avoiding the contemplation of the horrors of their situation.
Prince Andrew walked along the meadow dragging his feet.
Prince Andrew rustled the grass.
Prince Andrew gazed at the dust that covered his boots.
Prince Andrew took big strides trying to keep to the footprints left on the meadow by the mowers.
Prince Andrew counted his steps.
Prince Andrew calculated how often he must walk from one strip to another to walk a mile.
Prince Andrew stripped the flowers from the wormwood that grew along a boundary rut.
Prince Andrew rubbed the wormwood flowers in his palms.
Prince Andrew smelled the pungent, sweetly bitter scent of the wormwood flowers.
Prince Andrew had no thoughts of the previous day.
Prince Andrew thought of nothing.
Prince Andrew listened with weary ears to the ever-recurring sounds.
Prince Andrew distinguished the whistle of flying projectiles from the booming of the reports.
Prince Andrew glanced at the tiresomely familiar faces of the men of the first battalion.
Prince Andrew waited.
Prince Andrew heard an approaching whistle in the hidden region of smoke.
Prince Andrew thought, 'Here it comes... this one is coming our way again!'
Prince Andrew heard a whizz and a thud.
Five paces from Prince Andrew a cannon ball tore up the dry earth and disappeared.
A chill ran down Prince Andrew's back.
Prince Andrew glanced at the ranks again.
Many soldiers had been hit near the second battalion.
Prince Andrew shouted, 'Adjutant! Order them not to crowd together.'
The adjutant obeyed the instruction and approached Prince Andrew.
A battalion commander rode up from the other side.
A soldier shouted, 'Look out!' in fright.
A shell dropped within two steps of Prince Andrew and close to the battalion commander's horse.
The horse snorted, reared, and galloped aside.
The horse's terror infected the men.
The adjutant cried, 'Lie down!' and threw himself flat on the ground.
Prince Andrew hesitated.
The smoking shell spun like a top between Prince Andrew and the prostrate adjutant near a wormwood plant.
Prince Andrew thought, 'Can this be death?'
Prince Andrew looked at the grass, the wormwood, and the streamlet of smoke.
Prince Andrew thought, 'I cannot, I do not wish to die.'
Prince Andrew loved life, the grass, the earth, and the air.
Prince Andrew remembered that people were looking at him.
Prince Andrew said to the adjutant, 'It’s shameful, sir!'
Prince Andrew started to one side, raising his arm, and fell on his chest.
Several officers ran up to Prince Andrew.
Blood welled out from the right side of Prince Andrew's abdomen, making a large stain on the grass.
Militiamen with stretchers who were called up stood behind the officers.
Prince Andrew lay on his chest with his face in the grass, breathing heavily and noisily.
The peasants went up and took Prince Andrew by his shoulders and legs.
Prince Andrew moaned piteously.
The peasants exchanged looks and set Prince Andrew down again.
Someone cried, 'Pick him up, lift him, it’s all the same!'
The peasants again took Prince Andrew by his shoulders and laid him on the stretcher.
Officers shouted, 'Ah, God! My God! What is it? The stomach? That means death! My God!'
